title: Patterns in flax
creator_contributor_role: New Zealand National Film Unit, production company
subject_group: Anthropology, Ethnology, Exploration & Travel/Maori (New Zealand people)
Anthropology, Ethnology, Exploration & Travel/Maori (New Zealand people) - Social life and customs
Agriculture, Business, Commerce & Industry/Industries - New Zealand
description: The 6 foot leaves of New Zealand's native flax were invaluable mats and baskets from the almost unbreakable flax strips and made cloth and rope from the tough fibres. New modern factories use some of the beautiful old Maori designs to make modern floor coverings. Often the modern weaving machines are operated by descendants of the Maoris who used these fibres to make the fine material for their garments.
